entry.title: SAP Joule implementation in an S/4HANA private cloud 3 system landscape
entry.content:
While most customers choose to activate and run SAP Joule in a single-system S/4HANA Private Cloud landscape, I had the opportunity to implement it across a complete three-system landscape—DEV, QAS, and PRD. This approach brought additional complexity in terms of transport, configuration consistency, and cross-system validation, but it also ensured a more robust, production-ready deployment. Successfully enabling Joule in a full landscape setup is not just a technical task; it reflects a deeper understanding of SAP architecture, governance, and best practices. Delivering this implementation end-to-end has been a noteworthy achievement in my SAP journey. 

Sharing this experience is important because a three-system setup brings its own challenges, and I hope this blog will make the process clearer and easier for anyone working in a similar landscape. 

The steps for implementing Joule remain the same across landscapes, but there are several important considerations that need to be planned in advance before starting the implementation in a customer environment. 

Let’s get started. 

Architecture diagram 

1. BTP subaccounts and Cloud identity service 

For non-production systems (development and quality systems), we need to create two different subaccounts for each to enable the required Joule and Work Zone subscriptions and services. This separation helps maintain a clear landscape structure aligned with the backend systems.  However, it is recommended to use a common subaccount for the Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant, as it has only one connectivity service, and identity management should remain centralized for consistent user provisioning and authentication across both environments, and we are using non prod IAS tenants for both. 

 Tip: We can also integrate Joule without creating a separate subaccount for CIS by including CIS in the individual DEV and QA subaccounts, but in that case we need to create the RFC for the identity service from the DEV subaccount for the QA system by pointing this RFC to the QA system used when configuring the source system in IAS. 

2. SAP roles assignment to users 

Since Joule-specific capabilities are embedded within certain standard SAP roles, it’s important to ensure that end users who will be accessing Joule have these roles assigned. Without the required role assignments, users will not be able to utilize Joule’s features fully. For most customers, users already have their standard Fiori roles assigned based on their functional area—for example, a finance user typically has all the roles required for their day-to-day activities. 

Tip: Get a list of all the roles from the customer security team and make sure these roles are exposed to BTP in all three systems. It’s better to involve the security team here to get this step done. 

3. Technical and business catalog creation 

This step must be carried out in the development system. The technical and business catalogs required for the QA and PRD systems will also be created in DEV and then transported to the respective systems as part of the normal transport process. During production cutover activities make sure the transports for catalogs are moved to production systems. 

 Tip: If we are configuring Joule in unit test clients other than the DEV client, create catalogs and roles in the development client and then create a client copy transport to the Joule configuration client in the development system. The same applies for any other developments as well. 

4. Joule plugin role 

It is recommended to create three separate single roles for Joule when working in a three-system landscape. The business catalog created in the development system should be included in the DEV-specific role, and the corresponding catalogs for QA and PRD should be added to their respective roles and transported through the landscape. Assigning users the appropriate role for each system ensures that they can see the Joule icon upon logging into the Fiori Launchpad. This approach is essential to ensure that Joule correctly points to the intended BTP subaccount and retrieves data from the corresponding S/4HANA system. 

5. OData services activation 

Based on the required capabilities, identify the corresponding OData services that need to be activated in the system. Activate these services first in the development system, capture them in a transport request, and move the transport to the QA and PRD systems. In some cases, even after the transport is imported, the related ICF services may not be automatically activated in QA or PRD. In such situations, you must manually activate the ICF services. Ensure that the necessary authorizations are available for performing this activation. 

6. Cloud connector principal propagation 

Principal propagations set up in cloud connectors are an important step in Joule configuration. Make sure this is done in Non-Prod and Prod cloud connector.  During production cutover, we must obtain the required access to the production system to check the related parameters, CERTURLE, and certificates in the system. We must ensure access for this and get the fire fighter user if the normal user does not have the required authorization. For most production environments, there will be web dispatchers, and in such cases, we need to import the Cloud Connector certificates into the web dispatchers as well 

7. SSO for Joule 

In most production landscapes, customers expect Single Sign-On (SSO) to be enabled for Joule.  If an S/4HANA system is already configured for SSO using Microsoft Entra ID, you can extend the same setup to Joule by configuring Microsoft Entra ID as the corporate identity provider in SAP IAS and setting it as the default identity provider. Once this is done, SSO for Joule is automatically enabled. Users do not need to exist in the IAS user store for Joule to function, as authentication flows directly through Microsoft Entra ID. 

By taking care of all these steps, you can ensure a smooth and successful Joule implementation across a three-system landscape.

entry.title: SAP Joule Skill for Technical Completion of Maintenance Orders in S/4HANA Asset Management
entry.content:
This blog provides a brief overview of certain advanced functionalities, namely multiple action projects and if-condition expression, within a single JOULE Skill.

What is SAP Joule:

SAP Joule is an AI copilot that is grounded in organization`s business data. It aims to understand our requests, retrieve information, and complete our tasks using natural language in a conversational way.

  • Joule Skill :  It is a predefined capability that executes a specific task within the business context.
  • Joule Agent: It is a more advanced AI powered assistant that uses multiple JOULE Skills and other agents to complete complex tasks/workflows

If you would like a high-level overview of SAP JOULE , and how to setup an SAP JOULE skill using OData services, check out my latest blog post "SAP JOULE & ME : My First JOULE Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management Without Coding" by accessing the link below. This blog outlines the basic functionality of the JOULE skill used to create an EHS Incident in the S/4HANA system.

SAP JOULE & ME : My First JOULE Skill in SAP EHSM-Incident Management Without Coding 

My Business Use Case: TECO Maintenance Order with SAP Joule Skill.

In my maintenance procedure, a maintenance order can only be "Technically Closed (TECO)" if the system status contains both REL (Released) & CNF (Confirmed). This ensures that no order is prematurely closed without properly released and confirmed.

To achieve this functionality, I have designed an SAP JOULE skill that leverages:

  • Two Action Projects: This is to get the Maintenance Order Details and Performs Technical Closure.
  • An If Condition: This is to validate if the provided maintenance order has both REL & CNF statuses before allowing the TECO.

This approach enforces strict control mechanism and ensuring that the only valid maintenance orders reach the TECO stage.

Let us break it down step by step to see how this SAP JOULE skill performs the TECO for the maintenance order.

What is an Action Project:

Actions are used in SAP Build Process Automation to connect processes with external systems, be it SAP or Non-SAP system, and to make GET, POST, PATCH calls. The actions that are created here can be consumed directly in a JOULE Skill created in SAP JOULE Studio.

For instance, I have chosen OData V2 API : API_MAINTENANCEORDER for get Maintenance Order details and perform Technical Closure actions.

Now let us test the OData in the action project : EAM_Maintenance_Order_Management.

 

Mini Note: We must follow API guidelines when providing input values. We had better read the business documentation provided under the "Documents" tab in SAP API HUB.

First let us test the GET call : Get Maintenance Order Details by Maintenance Order Number.

Now let us test POST call :  Set Maintenance Order to Technically Completed. 

The API response was successful and status has been updated to TECO.

Once we release and publish the Action project, we can now create JOULE skill in SAP Build Lobby.

Let us setup Input Parameters for "TECO Maintenance Order" Joule skill. This field is used during the conversation with JOULE for TECO of the maintenance order.

As per our business use case, using this input value, i.e., Maintenance Order, we should first get maintenance order status details.

Let us use action project "Get entity from MaintenanceOrder by key" and map the values from the Joule skill input parameters to the action project input value.

If the Maintenance Order Status does not include the system statuses REL (Released) and CNF (Confirmed). the system should display an error message or else It should use the action "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted"

If the condition is satisfied, the system should execute the action project "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted".

As per SAP API documentation, the maintenance order must be enclosed in single quotes when we use POST call "Invoke action SetMaintOrdToTechCompleted".

To achieve this, I have maintained the expression to let the system automatically enclose the provided maintenance order number in singe quotes.

The expression for the condition to close the assigned notification is "true", and for the Maintenance Order, the expression should be as follows.

Now let us configure the "Error Message" when the maintenance order does not satisfy the condition.

For Instance, I have chosen message type as "Illustrated Message".

Now let us configure the "Successful Message" when the maintenance order satisfies the condition.

We can now "Release" and "Deploy" the JOULE skill in respective environment. Once we deploy it, our maintenance team can now interact with JOULE skill in natural language to "Technically Close" the maintenance order.

Let us now interact with JOULE to technically close the maintenance order.

Condition-1: If the system status of the maintenance order does not include the statuses "REL (Released)" & "CNF (Confirmed)", the JOULE skill should provide an error message.

Condition-2: If the system status of the maintenance order includes the statuses "REL (Released)" & "CNF (Confirmed)", the JOULE skill should provide a successful message.

😊This brings me to the end of the SAP JOULE skill set up for Technical Completion of the Maintenance Order. Stay tuned for more updates on SAP JOULE skills in Asset Management Space...

Key takeaway:

By combining two action projects with an If condition in a single SAP JOULE skill, we can build more flexible automations that respond to business logic in real time. 

 

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy. Chelikam

entry.title: What's New in SAP BTP - Q4 2025 Innobytes
entry.content:
Happy new year and welcome back to the SAP BTP Innobytes! 2026 is going to be an exciting year and we have big ideas and a strong strategy for the year ahead! In the meantime, let’s see how we finished out last year with some innovative highlights.

Check out the video below and explore the latest features in Application Development, Integration and more. Enjoy watching!

 

 

Data & Analytics

My Metrics

To keep up with the important numbers and data, let me introduce you to your personalized watchlist to keep up with what really matters: My Metrics in SAP Analytics Cloud on SAP BTP.

You can find it via the My Metrics Card on the new Homepage, bringing together performance cards from stories and models into one easy-to-access space with these core areas:

  • Your Metrics to manage cards
  • Detailed Visualization with instant charts and active filters
  • Smart Insights surfacing automated observations

You can create lists from My Metrics page or directly from a story chart: select a data point that you want to track and add it to an existing list or create a new one. You can name the metric and customize suggested comparisons and default visualizations. It’s now possible to rename, delete, copy or move metrics between different lists. You can Share multiple metrics with tailored permissions and distribute it with different SAC users or teams. 

See these steps in action (starting at 0:09).

Learn more

  • MyMetrics Blog Post

 

App Dev Highlights

Analytical Table with RAP and SAP Fiori

Real-time data analysis tools are essential for decision-making, that’s why SAP BTP ABAB introduced these powerful features for business users.

By adding the annotation @odata.applySupportedForAggregation: #FULL to your data model, you can now unlock advanced aggregation, grouping, and subtotalling directly in Fiori analytical tables. View real-time summarized business data, group by key fields, and dynamically sort and analyse profitability. This way you can simplify analytics for end users, enabling faster, data-driven decisions.

Watch the demo starting at 1:37 to get more insights.

Learn more

  • Developing Read-Only RAP Analytical Tables

 

SAP Build Extensibility Wizard now available in SAP SuccessFactors

You might already know the SAP Build Extensibility Wizard, supporting developers in process creation and UI extensions directly from Cloud ERP apps. This feature is now also available in SAP SuccessFactors.

In this example we want to simplify the process of requesting personal data from new hires in the onboarding process:

  1. Launch the process variant manager from the SAP SuccessFactors application and select the specific HR process you want to extend.
  2. To let the new hire know, that their data has been accepted, we want to add a step of approval. The wizard will walk you through the familiar steps to set up our extension.
  3. You can jump directly into SAP Build to customize this process.
  4. View the process from the SAP SuccessFactors application, reviewing the new hires and the personal data they have collected.
  5. HR will get a notification in the Task Center Inbox and can select approve, notifying the new hire.

The Extensibility wizard can now practice its magic in SAP SuccessFactors, delivering a better experience for our employees with SAP Build.

To watch this innovation example, start the video at 2:41.

Learn more

  • Extensibility Support
  • Understanding Extensibility
  • Extension types

 

Joule Studio Agent Builder

When it comes to making decisions for your business, transparency and control are essential. AI agents can help speed up the process but building AI agents that are both powerful and enterprise-ready is a challenge. How do you combine development speed with the governance and trust your business demands? 

Describe your business goals to your AI conversational Partner and let Joule build an agent that fits your needs. It automatically discovers tools and connects to external systems through the framework support for MCP. Giving the agent deep business context enables smarter decision-making. The timeline feature gives you full transparency, showing every step of the agent's logic, essential for debugging and governance. 

Start the demo at 4:21 to learn all about the Agent Builder in Joule Studio.

Learn more

  • Joule Studio Learning Series (Blog Post)
  • SAP Learning: Building your first Joule Skill
  • Joule Studio

 

Integration

Local OData API access & SAP HANA support in Edge Integration Cell

When it comes to manage persistence and monitoring in hybrid landscapes, integration is an essential step to make it more flexible.

Edge Integration Cell now supports SAP HANA as both a database and datastore, offering an alternative to PostgreSQL and Redis. If your landscape already runs on HANA, avoid maintaining separate persistence systems by unifying your data layer. One SAP HANA instance can be used for multiple Edge to keep everything consistent and centralized. To ensure the reliability of your integrations even if the cloud connection isn’t available, try the Local OData API access for your Edge runtime. You can retrieve message processing logs, data stores, and other runtime info through local GET APIs.

To use the Local API Access,

  • Activate the API Plan support to the cluster using the ELMO UI
  • Modify the configuration by adding a valid API Virtual Host and an API Virtual Host Key Alias

These settings are also available upon onboarding a new Edge node, allowing a stronger performance and visibility into your integrations. 

Watch this part (starting at 5:36) to get more insights.

Learn more

  • SAP Integration Suite
  • Local OData API Access in Edge Integration Cell Runtimes

 

Security

SAP Key Management Service

SAP Key Management Service (KMS) enables customers to manage encryption keys to business compliance and regulations. Group systems and keys in key configurations according to your requirements.   

The Primary Key is the active one for encryption. The SAP KMS supports Hold Your Own Key (HYOK) and Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) by importing Your Key. Revoke a key at any time by disabling or deleting it, leading to a shutdown of the connected systems, locking the data. When assigned to a KMS tenant, connect the system seamless via the UI. The four-eye-principle secures tasks like connecting a system or a key action.

To see this demo in action, watch the video (starting at 7:04).

 

Share your thoughts 

These videos are for YOU, and we would love to hear your impressions. How do you like the video? How can we improve the upcoming videos? Please share your feedback by liking this post or leaving a comment below.

Thank you for your support and happy viewing, sharing, and enjoying!

You Might Also Be Interested In

  • SAP BTP Garage: monthly LIVE webinar with hands-on use case walkthroughs and demos.
  • Unlocking SAP BTP: monthly podcast covering all things SAP BTP.

entry.title: My experience with Joule for Consultants PoC
entry.content:
Joule for Consultants; sentiments after a few weeks.

Key words: SAP; Joule; Joule for Consultants;

Introduction:

I was one of the lucky ones to join the Joule for Consultants (J4C) Proof of Concept. I have been using this product for quite a few months, and I would like to share my findings. Most of all I am quite positive.

Having a technical and development background I was very curious about where J4C could support me, knowing that there’s a Joule for Developers as well (and even free to use).

On a side note: this article is fully written by a human, even though it writes about the use of AI. The only em-dash you’ll find is in this sentence, and it’s right here: “—”.

What is Joule for Consultants (J4C).

According to SAP marketing, it is a silver bullet: “SAP Joule for Consultants accelerates SAP projects and cloud transformations with the most authoritative AI assistance grounded in exclusive SAP knowledge. It enables consultants to increase productivity with fast and reliable answers, minimize rework with expert-level guidance that improves every design decision, and deliver more operational efficiency by ensuring projects align with best practices.” There is a more descriptive landing page with a more concise description: “SAP Joule for Consultants is a conversational AI solution that accelerates SAP cloud transformations with expert guidance from SAP’s most exclusive and up-to-date knowledge base.”. You can even find a course on the learning hub.

Or, in my own words, Joule for Consultants is a chat based AI solution that lets you quickly search in SAP documentation, coding, OSS notes and knowledge base.

How did I use J4C?

If you start J4C, you get a prompt, stating “Message Joule…”. Straightforward and effective, in the style of other popular LLM AI’s.

There are a few shortcuts to help you in your way:

For example, the “Quick Links”, give examples of effective and less effective prompts. I like to read these quite often, as it helps in giving a more useful result.

And after this, the real journey starts. Let’s give a real-life example.

I was asked to maintain and change a few forms in SD, so I started with the question: “What are the best practices in SAP S/4HANA, private edition, for configuring forms for different types of sales documents?”. I found the result quite impressive. It shows an overview of sales documents, followed by best practices, technical configuration, document specific configuration, integration considerations, testing, common pitfalls and maintenance. It took input from the SAP Learning hub, the SAP OSS Notes, the online documentation and the SAP Community pages, combining it in one useful, comprehensive format.

This was a good introduction, but I was searching for a specific form. In hindsight, my question was not specific enough, so I asked for details: “Give me an example on how in customizing I can couple a document type to a specific form”.  A quite extensive list follows, including the customizing path, different transactions like NACE, VOV8 etc. It also refers to output types, condition tables and access sequences. Again, several related topics like troubleshooting, testing and best practices are included.

With this, I can almost start, but my client has a complex setup. So, I would like to know more about conditions records: “Explain how to maintain and test condition records for Output Determination in detail with examples.”

And voila, I have exactly what I need to start. This saved me several hours of digging or questioning my functional counterpart.

I tried the same questions in LeChat (Mistral), ChatGPT and Claude. Claude and LeChat show reasonable to good answers, although they are obviously missing the link to OSS notes. ChatGPT suggests SAPscript and SmartForms, next to Adobe Forms. Asking for more details about customizing or condition records yields answers, but all three of them have hallucinations when it comes to transactions, paths or Fiori maintenance apps. Especially ChatGPT is going in a different direction: it starts explaining BRF+.

Is Joule for Consultants always so spot on? Alas, no. Once you get in to more specialized functionality, like the dateline functionality in purchasing (sometimes used in the Retail and Fashion Management suite), it looks like J4C is missing relevant sources and documentation. It starts nice, but when asking for advice on enhancing the datelines J4C starts to hallucinate with non-existing or obsolete BAdI’s.

I also noticed that J4C oftentimes mixes input from sources describing Public Cloud solutions with Private Cloud solutions. This leads to confusing answers, but it still saves me a lot of time.

Development

Although it is called Joule for Consultants, as a developer I wanted to see the capabilities of judging (ABAP) source code. I specifically used ABAP, as the competitors mentioned earlier are good with JavaScript solutions. I uploaded a not very well-designed ABAP program (using an ALV) and used the predefined question:

The first result was OK-ish, but I was a bit disappointed after the previous results. So I asked Joule to elaborate: “Give me advice on how to improve the design of the program”. And oh my, this was good: I got a list of aspects where to improve:

  1. Architecture & Structure Improvements
  2. Error Handling & Robustness
  3. Performance Optimizations
  4. Code Quality Enhancements
  5. Modern ABAP Features
  6. Transaction Management
  7. User Experience Improvements
  8. Security & Authorization
  9. Testing & Maintainability
  10. Suggested Refactored Structure

This was way more than expected, and a lot more detailed. Again, the other LLM-AI’s are not that good with ABAP, but Joule 4C is impressive. Especially, digging deeper with questions like “Give me examples of Implementing dependency injection” and “Explain the pros and cons of each suggestion” gives understandable and valuable responses focused on ABAP development.

Conclusion

Overall, I am satisfied with J4C. It saves me a lot of time. The answers are always in context of SAP, and mostly up to date. This is a plus compared to the more open standard LLM AI’s, who mix in a lot of old ECC answers. J4C is not perfect yet, especially in less-used areas of SAP’s functionality, or when it mixes private (and on-premise) vs public cloud answers .

entry.title: Why Bringing SAP to Agentic SDK via Regular MCP Server Is Not Good Enough
entry.content:
Advocating Technology

Let me name things properly – we have lots of noise around AI. Companies are trying to jump into the technology because they think that Business AI is simple, that it is just a kind of ChatGPT that gets access to business data. Sounds simple, doesn’t it?

I strongly disagree! Bringing SAP data to an Agentic SDK, like Claude or SAP Joule, does not mean delivering Business AI. It is far away from even an understanding of business needs. I know, you start hating me 😊. And the only reason for the internal opinion in your head is that you are most probably one of the MCP bridge providers that think that wrapping APIs (I will not write “discover OData via MCP Server,” because the whole SAP community will hate me :D), or wrapping SAP tables/views, or wrapping SAP function modules is the way to bring SAP data to Business AI. 

How many posts do we see now on LinkedIn where people are happy like kids seeing data from an agentic SDK, e.g. Claude Desktop, returned by OData that is called via an MCP Server and shown as a table. Wow-wow! A list of Purchase Orders! As a table! Based on my utterance! C’mon people, we are not in 2017 when we, together with the SAP Conversational AI team, were happy to see such kinds of cases. Yes, 9 years ago it was innovation, not now. Why not post on LinkedIn that the same OData service draws an even nicer table in a standard SAP Fiori app showing a list of Purchase Orders with… OMG… DRILL DOWN!!! 😊

Why am I writing this? Just to emphasize that Business AI is an excellent technology that is now far beyond strange posts where people see SAP data in another UI than GUI or Fiori. Real Business AI returns investment, works autonomously, and understands data. For example, an AI agent that gets emails from customers with purchase orders from their systems confirming the deals we’ve made with them. That AI agent posts those emails to SAP, creating Sales Orders, for sure not using OData. Why not? Because there are two EntitySet calls you need to do to create a Sales Order via OData, and you need to be able to simulate a batch call; otherwise, you will get lots of Sales Order headers in your SAP productive system when the OData call for Sales Order Items has failed.

 Pic.1 Example from LinkedIn Article – Creating Sales Order via OData without Batch Mode

However, even creating a Sales Order from my example is not the biggest challenge for that AI agent.

The Biggest Challenge

SAP data and the “bridges” we build to connect AI agents with SAP via “regular” MCP servers, this is the biggest challenge we create for AI agents. Sometimes it seems that after allocating a really good business case, we are doing everything possible to push the AI agent to fail 😊.

SAP data preparation is the boring, but extremely essential, step here. We should think about what we feed to the AI agent when asking it to read an email and post a Sales Order in the SAP system. We need to give the AI agent a chance to query master data that is so essential for that AI automation scenario and allocate master data in a robust and reliable way, independent of how the customer names our services and products in their systems.

SAP Master Data Vectorization

Let’s see a simple example we have created using the ChatGPT UI showing how different AI agents will act if you prepare and only then bridge SAP data properly. We will use two MCP servers for this:

  • Regular MCP Server for SAP Data (any MCP server, we do not like to point fingers at someone’s solution; we’d like to advocate AI automation only)

  • Skybuffer AI MCP Server for SAP Data (here we have a data preparation layer where we vectorize SAP master data first)

 Pic.2 SAP Master Data Vectorization as a Data Preparation Step

See the Difference

Now let’s simulate a request from an AI agent that is working autonomously and has responsibility to create Sales Orders in an SAP production system with the maximum level of automation.

Here is a simple example of a regular MCP Server failure, just because the customer captured data in their system a bit differently from our SAP productive system:

Pic.3 Regular MCP Server for SAP Data – Failing on the Simple Case of Small Wording Differences

And now let’s see how easily and robustly an AI agent gets information from the same SAP system, but via an MCP Server that reads prepared SAP master data for AI automation:

 Pic.4 Skybuffer AI MCP Server – Easy and Robust Access to SAP Master Data

Now you see that 99% of all examples or success stories from LinkedIn about how fast we can create MCP servers to bridge SAP data and how reusable OData services are, are solutions that are far away from productive implementation (unless you are OK with getting a 50% automation rate 😊).

Conclusion

Indeed, MCP servers that consume OData, tables/views, etc. make sense for some steps in AI automation. However, we need to be very careful, and we should not mix hype with productive implementations. A good MCP server bridges prepared SAP data that an AI agent can consume to provide a maximal rate of automation that will reach 100% in a short time of productive usage. Saving on implementation ruins the impression of Business AI and reduces trust in it. Let’s not harm our overall revenue and investment return, and think twice whether the bridge we build for an AI agent suits the goal.

Imagine connecting the Skybuffer AI MCP Server to SAP Joule, making it able to understand user input by similarities. How powerful would your SAP Joule implementation be, and how smoothly would SAP Joule understand requests? Skybuffer AI runs on SAP BTP, providing a hidden but necessary layer for SAP Joule that can properly bridge your SAP on-premise data.

Closing Statement

Good luck with AI automation implementations, and do not hesitate to ask questions, collaborate, and bring technology to customers in a way they benefit from it, not just seeing the hype in it.

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Adoption Operating Model
entry.content:
Part 3 of the “Practical Implementation Blueprint” series

Goal of this blog: Help you run AI in SuccessFactors like a product you operate, not a feature you enable once, so adoption stays trusted, measurable, and release-aligned.

Continuation from Part 1 & Part 2

In Part 1, we covered readiness, governance, identity/permissions, and the activation roadmap across Joule, embedded AI, and extensibility. In Part 2, we focused on the change blueprint: leadership ownership, frontline manager enablement, and operationalizing “AI suggests; humans decide”.

Now Part 3 answers what customers hit after go-live:
How do we run AI like a product -- safely, predictably, and aligned to SAP releases : without chaos, adoption drop-off, or budget surprises?

Series navigation: If you’re just starting with this blog, I recommend reading the first two posts first, then continuing here with Part 3.

  • Part 1 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint
  • Part 2 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Change Management Blueprint
  • Part 3 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Adoption Operating Model (this blog) 😊

Executive Summary (2-minute read)

The challenge: Many AI initiatives fail to scale because operating ownership, risk controls, and value tracking aren’t designed for continuous AI change. Gartner has predicted that a significant portion of agentic AI projects will be cancelled due to cost, unclear value, or insufficient risk controls.

The solution: Treat AI as a product you operate, not a feature you “turn on once.”

What you'll get

  • A minimum viable COE with clear accountability (and practical time allocations)
  • A three-tier governance cadence that stays agile without losing control
  • A single intake model that stops “random cool ideas”
  • A release-aligned quality loop so accuracy doesn’t erode over time
  • AI Units governance patterns using SAP usage metrics + dashboards
  • EU AI Act–aligned literacy + employment-risk handling patterns

Time to value (practical guidance)

  • 4–8 weeks to stand up basic governance + intake + dashboards
  • 3–6 months to stabilize the quality loop and embed monthly steering rhythms
  • 6–12 months to reach predictable “product mode” cadence aligned to releases

0) Why an operating model is required in 2026

AI in SuccessFactors is not static. You’re operating in a world of:

  • Joule capabilities evolving and relying on correct setup and permissions (for example, “Access to Joule” prerequisites).
  • Premium AI consumption monitoring through AI Units usage metrics and dashboards.
  • EU AI Act obligations, including AI literacy measures (Article 4 + EU Q&A).
  • Employment-related risk handling, because employment/worker management use cases are explicitly highlighted under Annex III (recruitment/selection and worker-management contexts).

That’s why mature customers shift from “AI rollout project” to an “AI product operating model.”

The 5 most common failure patterns (and how this blog prevents them)

Failure pattern
What happensPrevention strategy (where in this blog)
1) Orphaned ownership“Everyone owns AI” = no one owns it. Backlog becomes political. Adoption becomes inconsistent.Section 2 (COE roles + time allocation), Section 3 (cadence + decision rights)
2) Permission driftRBP/security changes break Joule journeys; users perceive “AI is broken.”Section 1.2, Section 5 (RBP impact checks + regression)
3) Random innovationMany custom skills/agents get built without lifecycle, test, support, or retirement plan.Section 4 (single intake + scorecard + decision tree)
4) Budget shockConsumption spikes appear when scaling cohorts or launching high-usage scenarios.Section 7 (monthly governance + spike diagnostic)
5) Quality erosionAccuracy and usefulness degrade release-over-release; no one notices until trust collapses.Section 6 (weekly quality loop + classification + fixes)

1) Operating model principles (2026 rules of the road)

1.1 One program, three AI surfaces

AI shows up in three interconnected layers:

  • Joule (assistant experience and guided support)
  • Embedded AI (AI-assisted experiences inside modules)
  • Extensibility (Joule Studio / SAP Build) for custom agents and integrations

Operating model implication: One intake, one backlog, one cadence, one measurement framework.

Illustrative example (common pattern): Organizations that consolidate Joule, embedded AI, and custom skills under one Product Owner and one backlog typically reduce duplicated initiatives and clarify the “which AI to use when” confusion faster than split governance models.

1.2 Security and permissions must remain “in the room” forever

Joule experiences depend on correct setup and permissions. As a result, security changes can “break” AI journeys even when AI itself is fine.

Concrete example of impact (permission drift):

  • You enable a manager-facing journey that relies on viewing team data.
  • Security/HR later tightens RBP visibility.
  • Result: managers hit errors or incomplete answers and conclude: “AI is broken.”

Prevention checklist

  • [ ] Security/Privacy has a permanent seat in Product Council (Section 3)
  • [ ] Every RBP change includes an AI journey impact assessment
  • [ ] Regression includes your top 10 AI-supported workflows (Section 5)
  • [ ] Support team has a “Permission vs AI” diagnostic script (Section 6)

1.3 Human-in-the-loop maturity progression

Part 2 made this clear: “AI suggests; humans decide.” Part 3 operationalizes it with maturity:

  • Level 1 (Basic): Generic disclaimer (“review output”).
  • Level 2 (Functional): Use case–specific guidance (e.g., drafting content requires compliance review).
  • Level 3 (Optimized): Contextual guardrails at decision points + manager coaching routines + auditable workflow markers (e.g., “AI assisted” indicator) for sensitive contexts.

1.4 AI literacy maturity model (EU-aligned, practical globally)

EU AI Act Article 4 expects organizations to take measures to ensure sufficient AI literacy for staff using AI systems. Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles.

Level
All employeesManagersHigh-impact roles (Recruiting, ER, Performance)
FoundationWhat AI can/can’t do; basic safety; where to find help+ HITL responsibilities; escalation paths+ Regulatory context; documentation expectations
PracticedQuarterly tips / refreshersManager community of practiceScenario-based practice
AdvancedSelf-service help centerCoaching othersAudit readiness + policy updates

2) AI COE structure with time allocations (minimum viable)

You don’t need a giant COE. You need clear accountability.

Role
OwnerTime allocation (guidance)Primary accountability
AI Product OwnerHR/HRIT50–60% FTEOutcomes, backlog priorities, adoption targets
SuccessFactors Platform OwnerHRIT30–40% FTEConfiguration, RBP changes, release impact, regression
BTP / Integration OwnerIT20–30% initially (higher if heavy Joule Studio use)Connectivity, extensibility lifecycle
Security + PrivacyCISO/DPO rep10–15% FTEPolicy, access risk, compliance sign-offs
Change & Enablement LeadHR Comms/L&D30–40% FTEComms, manager readiness, AI literacy plan
AI Knowledge/Content CuratorCOE/Ops20–30% FTEApproved sources, quality loop fixes
Adoption & Insights AnalystHRIT/HR Analytics20–25% FTEDashboards, ticket deflection, failure analysis

Sizing guidance (practical)

  • Small (<5,000 employees): combine roles; ~2 FTE total
  • Medium (5,000–25,000): ~3.5–5 FTE
  • Large (25,000+): ~5–8 FTE initially; higher at maturity depending on custom agents scope

3) Governance cadence with agendas (make it boring and repeatable)

Tier A — Executive Steering (Monthly/Quarterly)

Duration: 60 minutes

Standard agenda

  1. Adoption dashboard review (15 min)
  2. Risk register + top 3 issues (15 min)
  3. AI Units consumption vs budget (10 min)
  4. Value delivered vs business case (15 min)
  5. Go/no-go decisions (5 min)

Tier B — AI Product Council (Biweekly, 60 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Usage trends + top issues from last sprint (15 min)
  2. Intake review: new requests + prioritization (20 min)
  3. In-flight initiatives: status + blockers (15 min)
  4. Next cycle planning: what goes live (10 min)

Decision aids

  • Prioritization scorecard (Section 4.2)
  • Quality loop summary (Section 6)
  • Capacity planning + AI Units budget view

Tier C — AI Ops Review (Weekly, 30 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Hot issues from last 7 days (10 min)
  2. Quality loop: top 5 feedback themes (10 min)
  3. Quick wins for this week (5 min)
  4. Escalations + handoffs (5 min)

Practical embedding of managers

  • Rotate 2–3 manager representatives through Product Council quarterly
  • Monthly “manager listening sessions” (30 min) to capture friction
  • Include manager feedback scores in Tier A dashboard

4) Intake and prioritization (stop “random cool ideas”)

4.1 Single intake form (required fields)

  • Persona + workflow
  • Value hypothesis + metric
  • Data sensitivity
  • Human-in-the-loop requirement (yes/no + why)
  • Operational cost (support impact)
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan

4.2 Prioritization scorecard (weighted, transparent)

Dimension
12345Weight
Business valueMinimal impactNice-to-haveClear benefitHigh valueStrategic3x
FrequencyQuarterlyMonthlyWeeklyDailyMultiple/day2x
ReadinessMajor gapsSome gapsMostly readyReadyPlug-and-play2x
Risk/ComplianceHigh riskModerateStandardLowMinimal-2x
Consumption/CostVery highHighModerateLowMinimal-1x

Priority score formula

Priority Score = [(Value × 3) + (Frequency × 2) + (Readiness × 2)] - [(Risk × 2) + (Cost × 1)]
Maximum possible: 35
Minimum possible: -15

Prioritization thresholds

  • 25+ = Fast track (next sprint)
  • 15–24 = Standard backlog (sequence by strategic fit)
  • 10–14 = Consider (needs strengthening or cost reduction)
  • <10 = Defer or redesign

4.3 Intake decision tree (edge cases)

NEW REQUEST RECEIVED
│
├─ Is this employment-related (recruiting, performance decisions, termination)?
│  ├─ YES → Risk = 4 or 5 + Security/Privacy review required
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Do we have 3+ similar requests from different teams?
│  ├─ YES → Consolidate into one initiative (avoid duplication)
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Does this require NEW data sources or integrations?
│  ├─ YES → IT/BTP Owner assesses feasibility first (may delay 1–2 sprints)
│  └─ NO → Continue
│
├─ Is estimated AI Units cost >20% of monthly budget?
│  ├─ YES → Requires Tier A approval before piloting
│  └─ NO → Product Council can approve
│
└─ OUTCOME: Score using Section 4.2 + add to backlog with priority band

5) Release alignment playbook (SuccessFactors + AI)

Treat each SuccessFactors release as an AI change event: permissions/config shifts can break journeys, embedded behaviors can change, and custom agents need regression.

5.1 Release impact example (illustrative)

If permissions for a manager process change but your regression doesn’t include “Joule + that process,” you can generate a wave of tickets and a trust hit that takes weeks to recover.

5.2 Minimum release checklist (copy/paste)

  • Preview: identify impacted AI journeys; regression (top workflows + custom agents); refresh enablement (“what changed” + safe scope)
  • Go-live + 2 weeks: daily monitoring (tickets + wrong/confusing themes); rapid fixes (content, guidance, permissions); escalate defects to SAP if needed
  • Post-release: reprioritize backlog; update manager starter tasks (Part 2) with new value

6) The quality loop (how you reduce wrong/confusing outputs over time)

The goal is not perfection on day one. The goal is a repeatable improvement mechanism.

6.1 Weekly loop: Capture → Classify → Fix → Validate

Step 2: CLASSIFY (weekly)

Issue type
DescriptionExampleTypical fix
A) Missing/unclear contentPolicy/process info missing or outdated“Can’t find updated parental leave policy”Update knowledge source
B) Permission boundaryUser expects access they don’t have“Manager tries to view data outside role”Fix RBP OR clarify guidance
C) Low confidence/misinterpretationWrong/unclear response“Misread internal acronym”Add clarifying content; narrow scope
D) Product defectPlatform behavior/error“Error with valid permission”Escalate to SAP support
E) Misuse/unrealistic expectationUser asks AI to do unsafe things“Draft termination letter”Strengthen guardrails + enablement

6.3 Example quality improvement (before & after)

Scenario: Joule helps users find learning opportunities.

  • Before: results too broad; users say “not helpful.”
  • Actions: improve learning paths content + add guidance on better phrasing + apply scope rules.
  • After: users find relevant results faster; repeat usage rises; you scale with updated guidance.

7) AI Units governance (prevent budget surprises)

SAP provides AI Units usage metrics and consumption summaries so you can operationalize consumption governance. You should monitor consumption alongside adoption and value.

7.1 Minimum controls

  • Assign an AI Consumption Owner
  • Monthly consumption review: actual vs planned, spikes by cohort/process, 90-day forecast and guardrails
  • Scaling rule: no new cohort expansion until consumption trend is stable (or budget approved)

7.2 Monthly dashboard (Consumption + Value together)

Track consumption next to value so finance doesn’t only see “cost,” and HR doesn’t only see “adoption.”

Metric
This monthLast month3-mo avgTarget
AI Units consumed[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Cost per active user[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Tickets deflected[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Ticket deflection value*[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Net value (deflection − AI cost)[_____][_____][_____][_____]

*Use your internal cost-per-ticket assumption (e.g., service desk fully loaded cost).

7.3 Consumption spike diagnostic (runbook)

SPIKE DETECTED (>20% month-over-month)
│
├─ New cohort added this month?
│  ├─ YES → Expected. Monitor for next 30 days for stabilization.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ New use case launched?
│  ├─ YES → Check if usage is appropriate. May need guardrails.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ Seasonal pattern (e.g., year-end reviews, open enrollment)?
│  ├─ YES → Expected. Plan for next year.
│  └─ NO → Investigate further ↓
│
├─ Heavy user outliers (top 10% using >5x average)?
│  ├─ YES → Interview users:
│  │     • High-value power users? → Good. Feature in case study.
│  │     • Misuse or bot-like behavior? → Restrict or re-train.
│  └─ NO → Escalate to SAP (possible platform anomaly)

Compliance layer (EU focus, strong practice globally)

8.1 AI literacy (Article 4) must be a run-state deliverable

Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles. Integrate it into existing learning journeys (e.g., new manager onboarding) rather than creating isolated “AI training.”

Audience 
Initial (onboarding)Ongoing (run-state)High-impact (annual+)
All employees15-min module: what AI can/can’t do; where to find it; basic safetyQuarterly tips + refresh for new featuresSelf-service help center
All managers+ 30-min module: HITL responsibilities; escalation; “AI suggests; humans decide”Manager community of practice (quarterly)Scenario-based refresher
High-impact roles
(Recruiting, Performance, ER)		+ 60-min module: regulatory context; documentation expectations; bias awarenessQuarterly scenario practice + policy updatesAudit readiness workshop

8.2 Employment-related AI use cases require special handling

Maintain an AI Use Case Register for employment/worker-management contexts: classification, controls (HITL, documentation), sign-offs, and change history.

9) Measurement: ATVS dashboard (Adoption, Trust, Value, Safety)

Adoption

  • Active users (7/30)
  • Repeat usage trend

Trust

  • “I understand what’s safe”
  • “I know how to escalate”

Value

  • Ticket deflection
  • Time-to-complete improvements for top HR tasks

Safety

  • Permission boundary incidents
  • Register coverage for employment-related use cases

10) Visual framework: how it all connects

INTAKE → PRIORITIZE → PILOT → QUALITY LOOP → SCALE
   ↓          ↓          ↓          ↓           ↓
Product    Tier B     Tier C      Weekly     Tier A
Council   Decision    Review      Ops        Approval
   ↑          ↑          ↑          ↑           ↑
   └──────────┴──────────┴──────────┴───────────┘
              GOVERNANCE CADENCE
                     ↕
           RELEASE ALIGNMENT (each release)
                     ↕
         MEASUREMENT (ATVS Dashboard)

Key dependencies

  • Security/Privacy sits across governance tiers
  • AI Units monitored at Tier C, reviewed at Tier B, and steered/approved at Tier A
  • Quality loop feeds Product Council priorities
  • Release alignment triggers regression testing across all active use cases

11) AI operating model maturity levels

Level 1 — Initial (Months 0–3)

  • Basic COE roles assigned
  • Governance forums established
  • First pilots running
  • Quality loop mostly reactive
  • Ad-hoc consumption monitoring

Level 2 — Defined (Months 4–6)

  • Formal intake process
  • Prioritization scorecard in use
  • Weekly quality loop operational
  • Release regression testing begins
  • Not all use cases have HITL clarity yet

Level 3 — Managed (Months 7–12)

  • Predictable consumption forecasting
  • Value metrics tracked consistently
  • Manager enablement scaled (from Part 2)
  • Proactive quality improvements
  • Release process becomes predictable

Level 4 — Optimized (12+ months)

  • AI embedded in HR operating rhythm
  • Self-sustaining quality loop
  • Consumption + value balanced
  • Release process predictable
  • Expanding to new modules confidently

Your practical goal: Reach Level 3 by month 9–12.

12) Templates (copy/paste)

12.1 COE RACI (starter)

  • AI Product Owner — outcomes/backlog/adoption
  • SF Platform Owner — configuration/RBP/release regression
  • BTP / Joule Studio Owner — custom agent lifecycle
  • Security/Privacy — risk acceptance + sign-offs
  • Enablement Lead — literacy + communications
  • Knowledge Curator — source quality loop fixes
  • Support Lead — incident/problem/change coordination

12.2 Intake form (starter)

  • Title + owner
  • Persona + workflow
  • Value metric
  • Safe scope + HITL
  • Data sensitivity
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan
  • Pilot cohort
  • Definition of Done

12.3 Release checklist (starter)

  • Review “What’s New” items impacting Joule/AI journeys
  • Regression: top journeys + custom agents
  • Enablement refresh (what changed + safe scope)
  • Support script update
  • Post-release monitoring plan

If you enjoyed this series, I’d really appreciate a kudo, it really encourages me to keep writing more blogs 😊

Final note

In 2026, the goal isn’t “AI go-live.” The goal is habit + trust + measurable value : maintained through an operating rhythm. If you treat AI as a product you operate (intake, backlog, governance, release alignment, quality loop, and ATVS measurement), you significantly increase your chance of scaling impact without losing control of risk or cost.

entry.title: Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management in SAP Cloud ERP 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP's ready-to-run public cloud ERP software solution.  

SAP Cloud ERP is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data, and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem–customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

 

In this blog post I’d like to outline the innovations for SAP Cloud ERP 2602 in the area of Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management. These are the topics that are covered:

  • Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP (6JN) 
  • Project staffing view for resource managers (6JO) 
  • Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects (1NT, 1Q4) 
  • Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans (1NT) 
  • Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March
  • Further innovations

 

Check out my video to get a glimpse of the new features:

 

In today's fast-paced business environment, running projects efficiently, on time, and on budget is more critical than ever. This release is packed with features designed to bring more intelligence, automation, and transparency to your projects, ultimately driving significant business value. We’ve focused on streamlining processes, enhancing integration, and even giving you a glimpse into the future with AI-powered assistance.

Let's dive into the highlights that will help you unlock new levels of project success.

 

Enhancements in SAP Project and Resource Management

 

Enhanced integration of project plan information with SAP Cloud ERP

In complex projects spanning engineering, manufacturing, and services, a major challenge is keeping project execution plans in sync with core financial and logistical data. A delay in a design phase, for example, has a direct impact on procurement timelines and billing dates. If this information isn't shared instantly between the project planning tool and the core ERP, decisions are made based on outdated information. To solve this, our 2602 release supercharges the integration between SAP Project and Resource Management, our solution on the SAP Business Technology Platform, and SAP Cloud ERP. Now, when a project manager adjusts a project plan – such as extending a phase – the system automatically synchronizes these date changes with the core ERP in real time.

This direct synchronization ensures that your financial, commercial, and logistical data within SAP Cloud ERP always reflects the most current project reality, empowering you to make reliable decisions based on a single source of truth. By automating the update process, you eliminate the need for project teams to manually replicate date changes across systems, which significantly reduces administrative effort and minimizes the risk of human error. This tight integration also lays the groundwork for faster billing cycles, as milestone completions in the project plan can now directly trigger commercial processes in the core system.

 

Figure 1: Improved integration of project plan information between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management, enables better decision-making in projects through reliable, up-to-date project plan information.

 

Project staffing view for resource managers

Resource managers are constantly juggling demands from multiple projects, and gaining a clear, consolidated overview of the staffing situation for a specific project can be a fragmented and time-consuming process. To address this pain point, we are introducing a brand-new SAP Fiori app called “Manage Request Assignments”. This powerful application is designed specifically for resource managers, providing a single, project-centric view of all resource requests. It shows at a glance which roles have been fully staffed, which are partially staffed, and which are still open, eliminating the need to dig through multiple screens and reports.

This new application provides resource managers with unprecedented transparency into the staffing health of any project, allowing them to instantly identify bottlenecks and open demands without extensive research. Having all the necessary information in one place, with direct navigation to take action, streamlines the workflow and dramatically reduces the time it takes to staff open requests and get the right people on the right tasks. Ultimately, a clear, holistic overview empowers resource managers to more effectively optimize staffing within a single project or re-allocate experts across multiple projects, ensuring your most valuable resources are deployed with maximum impact.

 

Figure 2: The “Manage Request Assignments” application allows users to efficiently view the resource request and assignment details at a project level.

 

Other Innovations in SAP Project and Resource Management

Additional enhancements introduced in SAP Project and Resource Management. For example:

  • Technical user flow coverage (client credential flow) for some APIs
  • Use of actual dates in scheduling
  • Consideration of working and none working days in scheduling
  • Ability to block certain file types during file upload
  • Additional details for tasks and collaboration project

For a complete list and more details please take a look into the What's new document for SAP Project and Resource Management

 

 

Enhancements in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

 

Allowing contingent workers (cost center procured) to record time on enterprise projects

Modern project teams are a dynamic blend of internal employees and external contingent workers. A significant process gap existed for contingent workers who were procured via a cost center, as they couldn't use the standard “My Timesheet” application to record time against enterprise projects. This made it difficult to get a complete and timely picture of all labor hours and costs. With the 2602 release, we have closed this gap. Now, these contingent workers can use the very same “My Timesheet” application as internal employees to record their time against the projects they are staffed on, creating a unified experience for the entire team.

This enhancement delivers a unified and simplified process where all project resources, regardless of their employment type, use a single application for time recording, which improves the user experience. You can now capture every hour worked against your project demands in one central place, providing a more accurate and timely view of total project costs and progress. Furthermore, the system automates the creation of the corresponding service entry sheet and goods receipt upon timesheet approval, significantly reducing administrative overhead and ensuring your suppliers are paid accurately and on time.

Figure 3: Project-based and cost center-based contingent workers can record time seamlessly in the “Manage My Timesheet” application, ensuring consistent tracking and better visibility across all engagement types.

 

Automatic removal of billing block for sales order billing plans

Milestone billing is a fantastic way to align payments with project progress, but it has often been hampered by a manual step. Once a milestone was achieved, someone had to go into the sales order and manually remove the billing block to make that item available for invoicing, a delay that directly impacts cash flow. We have now fully automated this process. Building on a feature from our last release, the system now automatically removes the billing block from the corresponding billing plan item in the related sales order the moment a project manager confirms the completion of that milestone in the project.

By completely automating this process, you eliminate the manual hand-off and inherent delays, allowing you to invoice your customers the very moment a milestone is contractually met. This directly accelerates your order-to-cash cycle and improves cash flow. This automation also removes a tedious and error-prone manual task, freeing up your project controllers and sales administrators to focus their expertise on more strategic, value-added activities. The risk of human error is entirely eliminated, leading to a smoother, more reliable, and more accurate billing process from end to end.

 

Figure 4: For sales order billing plan items which are created based on enterprise project or WBS element milestones, the billing block is automatically removed when the related milestone is completed.

 

Joule as project assistant (beta), planned to be available mid-March

Setting up a new project can be a complex and time-consuming task, often requiring project managers to navigate between three or four different applications to define the scope, staff resources, and release the project for time recording. We are incredibly excited to give you a preview of how we are solving this with the future of project management: the Joule Project Assistant. This is our generative AI copilot, and we are starting with a beta agent designed to radically simplify the creation of internal projects. Instead of clicking through multiple screens, a project manager can simply ask Joule in natural language, e.g. "Create a new pre-sales project for the 'Rising Star' initiative, starting next week and lasting for one month.". Joule can then propose a template, adjust dates, staff the project, and release it – all within a single, conversational session.

This AI-powered assistant promises dramatic efficiency gains, condensing a multi-application process into a single, swift conversation that saves significant time and effort for your project managers. The intuitive, conversational nature of Joule makes project creation accessible to everyone, drastically reducing the learning curve and empowering users to initiate projects quickly and correctly. By leveraging templates from successful past projects, the Joule agent also helps ensure that new projects are set up consistently and in compliance with your company's standards right from the start. We are currently running a beta program for this and encourage you to get involved! Register for the Customer Engagement Initiative via this landing page as of March 15, 2026.

 

Figure 5: The AI-powered solution assists users in rapidly setting up projects by leveraging similar past projects when the volume is high, and projects are repetitive in nature.



Other innovations in Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management

We know how critical it is to have a clear, unified view of project financials. That's why we’ve introduced the company code currency into the Project Cost report. Now, you can see a consolidated view of all your key cost figures including planned costs, actuals, commitments, and even project stock costs – all in a single, consistent currency. This provides a much clearer picture of your project's overall financial health and variance.

There is one important prerequisite to keep in mind: for the report to display in the company code currency, all the projects and WBS elements you select for that report must share the same company code. This ensures data integrity and accurate reporting. For a more detailed guide on this feature, I encourage you to check out the documentation on the SAP Help Portal.

Second, we’ve Improved system usability by segregating the profitability segment from settlement rules for clearer allocation and analysis. What does this mean for you? In the past, assigning profitability might have required you to set up a settlement rule. Now, for projects with revenue, you can assign the profitability segment directly to a billing WBS element using the "Assign" function. This is a much more direct and intuitive workflow. It saves you steps, simplifies the allocation process, and makes your analysis clearer and more efficient. As with all our features, you can find comprehensive details on this enhancement in the SAP Help Portal.

Finally, and this is something I’m personally very excited about, we are going beyond system features to build a stronger community. We are officially introducing the new CIP community – a collaborative space designed for our customers, partners, and SAP experts to connect. The goal is to build a powerful network where we can all share ideas, discuss best practices, and co-innovate on the future of enterprise and collaborative project scenarios. This is your platform to influence the direction of our products and learn from your peers.

If you are interested in joining this community and helping shape the future of project management at SAP, please reach out to my colleagues, Anke Junker anke.junker@sap.com or Varsha Chetan Manu varsha.chetan.manu@sap.com, to get involved.


The SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release for EPPM is all about making your project management more connected, automated, and intelligent. From ensuring a single source of truth to simplifying daily tasks for every project role, these innovations are designed to deliver tangible business value and set you up for success.

Thank you for your time, and I look forward to seeing how you leverage these new capabilities.

 

 

📽️ Watch the replays of our SAP Cloud ERP 2602 Early Release Series!

From January 12-16, we hosted a series of 22 expert-led live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP Cloud ERP 2602 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management as well as 21 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand – anywhere, anytime.
